paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine induce an interferon-rich tumor state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled murine tumor-model experiments testing intratumoral mRNA vaccination in combination with anti-PD-L1 treatment for tumor control.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched murine control arms used to contextualize combination effects, including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle conditions.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective analysis of metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort with documented prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination exposure before or around ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, used as the comparison group for survival analyses.

major_limitations: Human analysis was retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
